author: Jay Clark
title: AFL to release a video to end ugly jeering at the football | The
text:
EXCLUSIVE: THE AFL will launch a powerful new campaign designed to end the ugly jeering that has divided football.
From tonight, the AFL’s broadcast partners will show a video clip promoting responsible barracking at games.
The video could also be shown on big screens at stadiums during games this weekend.
The 30 second video is the latest step from the league in a bid to stop the booing that threatens to prematurely end Adam Goodes’ career.
The video shows fans from various cultural backgrounds positively supporting their footy heroes.
The clip will be accompanied by an open letter from AFL CEO Gillon McLachlan and a social media campaign including the hashtag #AFLManyColours.
GOODES BOOING: PLAYERS CALL FOR RESPECT
It is hoped the video will promote inclusiveness, tolerance and understanding among fans.
When asked about the campaign, a league spokesman today said “the primary message is that the game is made up of many colours”.
Clubs have already been told about the campaign and have given their full support.
Sydney Swans players stand in solidarity showing support for teammate Adam Goodes during a press conference on Thursday. Picture: Phil Hillyard Source: News Corp Australia
McLachlan penned an open letter to fans that was released on Friday afternoon pleading for AFL fans to respect all players and stop the booing of Goodes.
“To move forward we need to listen to each other, and at present that means understanding the impact this issue is having on a man who has given extraordinary service to Australian football,” the letter reads.
“Whether you agree or not, the booing of Adam Goodes is perceived by him and many others as being racially motivated and that’s hurting us all.
“Adam is hurting, as are his family and close friends, and the game we love is hurting.
As it has always been, it is up to us, as supporters to respond.
“It’s Australia’s game and always will be and I have no doubt supporters will follow the lead of players and coaches who acknowledge Adam Goodes as one of our great champions, and a man who commands respect.”
Originally published as AFL to launch video to stop jeers
